question: Phone call. Malaysia.
answer: Kamal? Right. I'm getting them. I'm looking at the blueprints of K.L. right now. The belts are too small for the sorters. Yeah, sometimes you never see what's right in front of your face. Look, it's -- Hold it! Hazardous material needs its own container! -- three in the afternoon there, right? That gives you five hours until the sweep comes through. Do the sort by hand tonight, then put in a new feeder belt, say a twenty-four incher. Yes, overtime is authorized. I'm going out on every route, I'm going to work every job here, until I know enough to help you. That's it.

question: It's bad.
answer: Worse than Warsaw.

question: Nobody remembers that.
answer: The failures they remember. It's the successes they forget. You sorted your packages before you left. None of the other drivers did.

question: The failures they remember. It's the successes they forget. You sorted your packages before you left. None of the other drivers did.
answer: He says he wants to be organized. Do packages in order.

question: So how come the other drivers haven't left yet?
answer: He says -- he is a very rude fellow --

question: Tell me exactly what he said.
answer: He says why don't his farts smell sweet? He says that's just the way it is.

question: Give it five minutes. Let's go. That's Bermuda. Bermuda is in the Memphis thru container. No, Azores is Europe. The Paris container. Africa too. Japan goes to Memphis. Great job, everyone. Remember, work together. We are like a hand... You got it. I absolutely, positively, have to get to Memphis overnight. Jack -- gotta be something wrong with our physicals, you keep getting certified to fly. Gwen, aren't you worried? We're on time, right? Little present from the emerging republics. What connects the world? What makes it one? We do. FedEx.
answer: What do you expect, from the guy who stole a kid's bicycle when his truck broke down?

question: Borrowed. I borrowed it.
answer: How'd it go?

question: Great. Terrific. The good guys won one for a change.
answer: I had to bump your plane last night.

question: You what?
answer: It was fifteen minutes late.

question: I checked the weather, you had the jet stream, you could have made it up.
answer: But I might not have.

question: Jesus. I got it working... You have no idea how hard it was... They're finally a team...
answer: I'm touched.

question: You fucked us over.
answer: The point of FedEx, as I understand it, is to make the damn connection.

question: I was making a point.
answer: What? Let Paris hold its plane? Let Memphis take care of it? Let somebody down the line clean up your mess?

question: Every person counts, every package counts, that's my point.
answer: You know what your problem is? You just see the packages in front of you. You don't see the big picture.

question: Baloney. I do see the damn "big picture."
answer: I didn't know we had sailboats.

question: It's a ketch Kelly and I had chartered.
answer: For all those vacation days you got coming.

question: And never take.
answer: Look, I'm sorry about your plane. But I couldn't risk being late into Memphis.

question: Forget it.
answer: You know General McLelland, he wouldn't attack unless he had everything just right. Finally Abe Lincoln came to him and said, General, if you're not going to use my army, could I borrow it for a while? So he gave it to Grant and Grant just said, let's go.

question: I'm from Arkansas. Tell me a story with Robert E. Lee in it and maybe I'll pay attention.
answer: We're warriors, not desk jockeys. We've got to be bold. You always want all your ducks lined up. But nothing's 100 percent. It's always 60-40, maybe 51-49. Hell, I'd take 40-60. Then roll the dice.

question: That's why you're a gambling man.
answer: That's why I'm running foreign and you're not. That's why you're not married and I am.

question: For the third time.
answer: Take the plunge, admit your mistakes, move on to tomorrow. That's FedEx, that's women, that's life.

question: You are one sick fucker.
answer: I'm trying to help you here. There's Warsaw, there's this --

question: This was nothing like Warsaw. I held the truck then minutes, it's not that big a deal.
answer: Look, that kids' bike, that's a guy who'll do what it takes to get there on time. Live up to your legend, that's all I'm saying.

question: A hundred rubles St. Petersburg hits 95 percent in a month.
answer: Ninety five percent? Just give me the money now.

question: Talk is cheap. Are we on or not?
answer: We're on.

question: Let's go off-line. Two Valium...
answer: And the Stones. Got to be. Chuck. Wake up Chuck. You gotta do your own delivery from here.

question: Damn thing. Sorry, I'm really sorry. You seen Kelly Frears?
answer: Sonofabitch!

question: Hey, be nice to it, it'll be nice to you.
answer: Chuck! You're back! Your eyes are puffy. Did you take Valium again?

question: You smell like formaldehyde.
answer: My last chapter's in there, and the damn machine's jammed.

question: Let's take a look.
answer: How was Russia?

question: Cold.
answer: Don't overwhelm me with details, you know how I hate that. Did you get it fixed?

question: I thought I did. Got to follow the paper path here.
answer: Chuck, forget the Xerox. So Russia didn't turn out well?

question: Used to you could fix these yourself.
answer: Chuck.

question: What do you want me to say? That I thought I'd done a great job but it all turned to shit? That I might as well have gone sailing for all the good I did?
answer: Yeah, tell me. Tell me all of it. You don't even know what time it is. What day it is.

question: And I can't fix this damn machine.
answer: Come on. We're on the deck of the ketch, the air's soft, the water's clear as crystal...

question: That's carcinogenic.
answer: We're covered with suntan lotion and sweat. Our skin is so hot, it's glowing... We could take a swim.

question: Jim's a terrific financial man, no question. But we can't always parachute in from Memphis. We've got to build up our local staff. We're building a new team here. We got every package on the truck for the first time ever. Success is the best teacher.
answer: Merry Christmas eve.

question: Not if you work for FedEx.
answer: You break four million packages last night?

question: Four four. A record.
answer: You don't seem too happy about it.

question: Ah, the staff meeting could have gone better.
answer: Let me guess, Russia came up?

question: One of those packages just moved.
answer: Merry Christmas.

question: Hey, look at you.
answer: I figure, if we could take care of a puppy, we could, you know, take care of --

question: He is a cute thing.
answer: He's your cute thing.

question: I can't even keep fish alive.
answer: A puppy's got a little more personality than a fish.

question: And for you --
answer: So do good things come in large packages?

question: You know, for when you travel.
answer: For when I travel? You should have got me something that shows you want us to be together, not apart.

question: I wasn't sending a message. I though you'd like it.
answer: You should have got me a ring.

question: I have to go. I'm on call for overflow down at the Hub.
answer: A ring. I wanted a ring.

question: You did? Look, I love the puppy. I love you. But I have to go.
answer: You can't go now.

question: I have to.
answer: You want to.

question: What should we call him? Or is it her? How about Jango?
answer: This isn't working out.

question: We're a little emotional here. It's Christmas, maybe we're over-reacting.
answer: "We're" not over-reacting.

question: Could you watch Jango?
answer: No.

question: I can't take him to work. We'll talk about it when I come back. It'll all be fine. Really. Kelly? Kelly? There. There. Easy now. Kelly?
answer: What happened to your pants?

question: Mom, meet Jango.
answer: Chuck?

question: Dessert. Speaking of hatching, I could sure use some more grandchildren.
answer: Mom, this is a farm. We've got real strawberries growing outside, we've got real cream.

question: Oh no, the prodigal son's home. We bring out the store bought.
answer: Maybe I should take a few days off. Roger's working now, you could use some help around here...

question: Don't you even think about it.
answer: The place is falling apart.

question: I'm doing fine.
answer: Doing great, Mom, don't worry about me.

question: There's settled folks, and there's nomads. You're just not a settled folk. You never belonged here.
answer: Come on inside, Mom. You've had a long day. I need the latest PDRs on St. Petersburg. Terrific. Yours? And get me in to the dentist. My tooth's acting up.

question: Call Operations. Get me on it.
answer: That's your dog.

question: It's our dog. It belongs to us.
answer: There isn't any us.

question: Yes there is.
answer: I'm sorry about the presents. I got a little carried away.

question: No, it was great. Maybe a little overkill --
answer: I burned the Christmas tree. Why didn't you come over, get mad at me, tell me what a stupid bitch I was.

question: I guess I hadn't thought through how I felt.
answer: What, you were going to come over the next day all calm and say, Kelly that really made me mad? Don't tell me you're mad. Be mad. Be who you are right now.

question: Look, we'll do our trip as soon as I get back.
answer: Don't even start. Get back? From where?

question: Malaysia. They're holding the sweep.
answer: Give him to me. Chuck, you're breaking my heart.

question: A week, max. Okay? Okay?
answer: Go on. We'll be fine. I'll feed Jango to the frogs.

question: All right, guys. I'm here. Check the GPS, get moving.
answer: The full moon shines a ghostly light on the beach. Trees cast moon-shadows on the sand. Chuck seems very, very alone.

question: Where the fuck are you? Sonofabitch. That was smart, really smart. Ahhh. Maybe the GPS malfunctioned. That Korean airliner did. Okay, do the math. Maybe they know where you are within, say 500 miles. That's a circle with an area of, uh, pi r squared. So, uh, 250,000 times three point one four, that's about 800,000 square miles. Three times the size of Texas. They could use a satellite. Say each satellite photo is 30 feet square, that's uh...fuck it...billions and billions of photos. Aw, someone will come.
answer: Chuck sleeps by the coconuts. The tide is coming in. Chuck stirs, gets up, staggers over to a palm tree to relieve himself.

question: What the hell?
answer: Chuck splashes into the gentle surf, reaches the dark object.

question: Oh Jesus.
answer: Chuck drags the body up on the beach and then collapses, exhausted. He sits by it, staring at it.

question: I'm so sorry, Al. So sorry. Got to cover Al up. Got to cover Al up.
answer: With a rock Chuck hammers a crude driftwood marker into the sand.

question: We all live in a yellow submarine, yellow submarine... Yellow submarine. We all live in a yellow submarine... Bad idea. Should have saved some. Other than that, Mrs. Lincoln, how did you enjoy the play? Shit! Got to get there. Got to see. C'mon... c'mon. Don't be such a wuss. Be bold. No way on. No way off. This is bad. Really, really bad. Come on. Crawl if you have to. Got to drink. Got to drink something. They don't belong to you. Got to have shade. Got to have a hat.
answer: Chuck finishes the P on H E L P, which he has spelled out with the FedEx boxes on the beach.

question: Chuck breaks open another coconut and gulps down the milky liquid. With a stone knife he digs in the shell for some of the meat, but it's dry and chewy and fibrous. He spits it out, then lies back on the sand and stares at the first stars. Half sings to himself.
answer: You deserve a break today... Damn fish!

question: Discouraged, he sits down on the beach and gets his breath.
answer: Wait a minute. Wait just a minute. Don't leave home without it. Yuck. Yumm. Got to get this fixed. Water, water, everywhere, water, water everywhere... Where's the water on this fucking island? Just rest a minute. Oh yeah, oh yeah, oh yeah. Let's see, I waited two days. Then I buried Al. Al. You never made it home, buddy. Then American Express got me those clam things... I dug all those damn holes, the clouds over the moon... And today, the historic discovery of H, Two, Oh. Ten days. Shit.

question: He resumes his efforts at fishing. A shape scuttles raggedly beneath him.
answer: A crab, it's a crab. Dammit! I did it. I did it! Jesus. Stupid fucking thing! I don't know what I did, God, but whatever is was, I am really, really sorry. You hear me? Really sorry.

question: Chuck emerges from the jungle and walks to the edge of the ocean. He dips his blistered hands into the sea water, then looks over at the FedEx boxes that spell out H E L P.
answer: Don't have a choice, do I?

question: That's the big dipper...Orion...or is that the Southern Cross...? Kelly would know.
answer: Chuck readies his two sticks of bamboo again and begins sawing with tremendous energy. He smells something. Is it smoke? He pulls off the log and looks eagerly at the nest of tinder. There's nothing there.

question: Dammit! Careful now, careful... Yes! Yes! Yes! If I ever forgot to thank you God, and I am sure I did, thank you now.
answer: Chuck wades in the water with his spear. Suddenly he stabs it down. A crab is on the end.

question: Damn tooth!
answer: Using a safety pin and some suturing thread, Chuck fishes carefully. Suddenly he jerks his hand back. On the end is a flopping fish.

question: Save some for tomorrow.
answer: Catch another fish tomorrow. Shit! Shit! Shit!

question: Stay calm, identify the problem. Problem, rope fraying. Solution, fix rope.
answer: With what? There's nothing to fix it with. This rope comes undone, you're going to drown. Too tired.

question: Get up.
answer: Feels so good to lie here.

question: Get up, damn you.
answer: Can't. Need water.

question: You've had today's water.
answer: Thirsty.

question: Come on, shape up, get going, you can do it.
answer: No water, no work.

question: Okay look, I know you're tired, I know you're thirsty, but give it one more shot, you've just got to do a little more.
answer: Do too much, I'll die.

question: Do too little you'll die.
answer: Going to die anyway.

question: Okay, look have an extra swallow.
answer: No more water, you said.

question: Take it.
answer: No.

question: Take it, damn it.
answer: No.

question: Wilson, do you believe this? Take the damn water. Stop. Enough. Think. Got to use something else.
answer: If they can't see you, what's the point?

question: Survive today, that's the point. Polaris, where are you? Maybe I'm too far south.
answer: You don't know where you are. You missed the shipping lanes.

question: Moon's too bright.
answer: You're putting off the inevitable.

question: I'm putting it off.
answer: That's what's happening to you. You're rotting away. Get water!

question: Fix raft first.
answer: Water water water --

question: What are you doing?
answer: Can't kill another one. Can't. Can't kill my friends anymore.

question: You fucking bleeding heart, you kill or you die.
answer: Why do they have to die for me?

question: They'd eat you if they could. They're laughing at you. Listen.
answer: Got to eat. I am so sorry.

question: I'm an angel. Here! Here! No...no...no...
answer: Clouds are building up. In the distance lightning flashes. The clouds come closer.

question: Sea anchor! Let out the sea anchor!
answer: The storm has passed. The raft floats on big dark rollers.

question: You're falling apart. First you eat your fat, then you eat your muscle. Then you eat your mind.
answer: Roll on you deep and dark blue ocean roll. I'm late, I'm late, for a very important date.

question: I'm lost. Goodbye.
answer: No!

question: Look, just slip off the raft. The ocean would feel so good, the water's so soft and warm. Take a little swim. Sleep.
answer: You quitter you quitter you quitter.

question: The sea is lovely, dark and deep.
answer: But I have promises to keep. And miles to go before I sleep. And miles to go before I sleep. Got to fix the sea anchor. Use the sail.

question: Use the sail for a sea anchor and you won't move.
answer: If I don't have a sea anchor I'll capsize.

question: Die tomorrow or die today. That's death knocking, knocking on your door. Crazy little woman come knocking, knocking at my front door...
answer: Grow up, stop being such a baby. Other people get through a lot worse.

question: Yeah, sure, what? I'm so tired, my mind is on the blink...
answer: What? Are you sacrificing yourself for me? Damn it! I had to do it! I'm sorry! I know there's a moral here, God, but right now I'm just going to eat. Forgot to say grace. Sorry Mom. Bless us O Lord, and these thy gifts and Christ and the bounty about to receive, or something...amen. Please don't leak. Please. Don't look at me. It was that Dorado. You know, Wilson, every now and then we should say thank you. Thank you God.

question: Thank you for fucking up my life.
answer: Not again.

question: He's going to get you, going to get you...
answer: Get away from me! Get him get him get him. Where are you? Where are you? Stop! You're using energy. Move slowly. Be patient.

question: What are you smiling about? They'll be back.
answer: I'm dancing on the roof of the Peabody Hotel. With Kelly. The music ends. We go back to the table. The waiters have brought dinner. New York Strip with Bordelaise Sauce. Mushrooms in brown gravy. Roasted potatoes with garlic and rosemary. Green Beans with almonds. Fresh biscuits and cornbread, dripping with butter. A nice salad with ranch dressing. A jumbo shrimp cocktail. No shrimp. We eat. For dessert, we have pecan pie a la mode, we have a double chocolate cake with creme anglaise, we have a nice pear torte, fresh key lime pie, or perhaps if you care to wait a few minutes, a grand marnier souffle? Why, bring them all, bring them all. Here! Over here!

question: They're never going to see you. You're just another piece of trash in the ocean.
answer: They're on autopilot.

question: They're always on autopilot. Or else it's night, or you're in the sun, or you're in the trough of a wave. They'll never see you.
answer: Damn it! Don't be so negative! Wilson, what's your story?

question: I float. You sink. End of story.
answer: I'm serious. I'm always going on about me, me, me. Enough about me. Your turn.

question: It's a fucking soccer ball, you idiot.
answer: Shut up. Don't shirk, don't procrastinate, don't be lazy. We're okay today. We're okay today. Shut up. Shut the fuck up! I mean it. What's so damn funny?

question: You are.
answer: Jesus.

question: Look again, asshole. It's a mirage.
answer: It's real.

question: Nothing out there but ocean.
answer: Let's get a second opinion. Wilson? What do you see?

question: Please, no sharks. Jesus. Jesus. Jesus. Shit! Wilson! Wilson! Thank you. Oh thank you. My favorite doctor. What's the verdict?
answer: Under the circumstances your overall health is good. Those salt water boils you picked up on the raft are ulcerated, but they're healing nicely. Hemoglobin's 10.8 -- you're anemic, that's why we're giving you iron. Potassium's low -- we're giving you an electrolyte solution with your IV. Sodium's over 150, way too high. You may experience swelling in your extremities as you rehydrate and discharge the salt. In spite of your dietary deficiencies there's no sign of mental deterioration. What's so funny.

question: Sorry...sorry... Why do my joints still ache?
answer: Dehydration. Vitamin deficiency. Protein deficiency. Any or all of the above.

question: All I ate was fish. That's solid protein.
answer: Protein digestion is very costly in water usage.

question: Which I didn't have.
answer: And fish are very low in fat, which is energy inefficient. So you're going to burn up your own cells no matter how much you eat. Luckily you ate the eyes and pancreas, which contain some Vitamin C, so you didn't get scurvy.

question: I am one lucky guy.
answer: Your body chemistry and your exposure to the elements would normally lead to irritability, depression, anxiety, periods of self-reproach. It's almost like schizophrenia. Different sides of your personality might come to life, speak out, act out.

question: But all that's behind me. I'm fine now.
answer: If you say you are.

question: I most definitely say I am.
answer: Doctor Hegel tells me he discussed the Vietnam POW syndrome with you.

question: Yes, yes he did.
answer: You are aware of the potential disruptiveness on your loved ones when you return to your old life?

question: Not to mention on me.
answer: You sure you don't want some counseling?

question: Doc, I'm not on the island. I'm not on the raft. I'm alive. I'm so glad to be back, I can't tell you. I just want out of here.
answer: Well, when that IV runs out, you're through with us. Just the dentist tomorrow.

question: Hello?
answer: Stan, it's Chuck...Chuck Noland...

question: Whoever you are, you are one sick fucker.
answer: Two Valium and the Rolling Stones. That ring a bell?

question: God damn! God damn! Chuck, it's you!
answer: It's me.

question: You're fucking dead!
answer: I'm most definitely not dead. And as I recall, you're the sick fucker.

question: I'm sorry... I'm sorry...
answer: Hey...hey...it's okay!

question: You're so thin. Am I hurting you?
answer: No...no...feels good...

question: Right back, you said you'd be right back.
answer: A few things came up. Or went down. You look...wonderful. I like your hair.

question: I got married.
answer: I thought you might have.

question: I would never --
answer: I know.

question: If I'd known you were alive --
answer: I would have done the same thing.

question: I didn't want to. It just happened. One day Gary was there. He took care of everything. He took care of me. I was a mess.
answer: You have any children? Got a picture?

question: Her name's Hannah.
answer: Is that Jango?

question: No, this is Jack. Jango was hit by a UPS truck. Can you believe it?
answer: Life's just one big joke after another.

question: Life's just one big joke after another.
answer: How about we go somewhere else?

question: Want to see my raft?
answer: This stinks really bad.

question: You should have smelled me.
answer: Cool ropes.

question: I braided them.
answer: Must have taken a hell of a long time.

question: Forty-three days.
answer: All that time I waited to go on a cruise, and you went without me.

question: Yeah, well...couldn't be helped.
answer: What's that, written on the sail?

question: I buried you, Chuck. They had to pry my fingers off your coffin.
answer: There was a coffin?

question: Yeah, coffin, headstone, the whole thing.
answer: What was inside?

question: Your calendar, your cell phone, your whoo pig sooey hat, some pictures of that ketch you wanted.
answer: That about sums it up.

question: Maybe now's when you tell me about it.
answer: The plane went down. My friends died. I washed up on an island. Then I found these barrels, built the raft, and here I am.

question: Yeah?
answer: The tide came in, the tide went out. I survived. That's the headline. I survived.

question: Don't overwhelm me with the details. You know how I hate that. Come on. Try.
answer: Cliches, mainly. Don't take anyone for granted. Don't sweat the small stuff. Live each day like it's your last.

question: So simple to say, so hard to do.
answer: Not when you have no choice.

question: You hated being alone. Couldn't stand it. Busy every minute. Always plugged into something.
answer: I didn't know what really being alone was. No one back here does. We're not meant to be alone. Not like that. Share life, that's what came to me out there. Be with someone.

question: This is so unfair.
answer: That's what I told the fish I caught. But I ate them anyway.

question: You okay?
answer: Great. Really.

question: What will you do?
answer: I don't know. I really don't know.

question: I've got to get back to Memphis. Hannah's babysitter has finals.
answer: It means a lot...that you came.

question: I had to come. To be sure you were okay. I love you, Chuck.
answer: You too.

question: I'm so glad you're alive.
answer: You too.

question: When I first showed up, I thought you'd lost your fucking marbles.
answer: I never thought it would end. Then it did. It was so great to be saved, I couldn't stop laughing.

question: You need a drink.
answer: For years my only drinking buddy was a soccer ball. Wilson.

question: To Wilson.
answer: To Wilson.

question: So, what's it all about? You've been over the line and you came back. You've been saved, hallelujah!
answer: Hallelujah.

question: I'm serious. The burning bush, the big picture, the words in neon...
answer: What's it all about? It's about being so thirsty you'd crush a fish's backbone to suck out the spinal fluid -- that's what it's about.

question: Do what it takes. That's what I always told you. To life. Fuck 'em if they can't take a joke.
answer: To life.

question: That's all there is.
answer: Believe me I know. But it's not being bold or being in the game or rolling the dice. When I was going crazy, on the raft, I'd argue with myself about everything. Because everything had a price. To get anything -- a sip of water, a little corner of shade, an hour's sleep -- I had to let go of something else. And then I could never get it back. You don't win or lose. You win and lose. You win and lose.

question: Where's Mom?
answer: Waiting for you. At the farm. This was too much --

question: Tell me about it.
answer: Glad you made it, big brother.

question: Wow. Thank you. Great. Thank you. Hey, Rasheed, how you doing? Thank you all. Thank you. Thank you very much... Give me a minute. I've spent four years looking out at an empty ocean. It's all so -- big. You never think you'll miss -- all this. But I did. I really, really did. And I missed all of you. You've added some new belts, and what's that?
answer: Digital laser readers.

question: Digital laser readers. Wow. Terrific. I've never heard it this quiet. Shouldn't you all be getting back to work? Take your time.
answer: What?

question: That's what it's about.
answer: Being patient. Don't rush things. I get it.

question: Not just that. Take your time. Use it. Live it.
answer: Deep, real deep. So where to? The office? The hotel? The beach? What, then?

question: Deliver this package. Then, I dunno.
answer: You want that delivered, we'll deliver it. That's what we do.

question: I need to do it.
answer: Finish what you started. You haven't changed, Chuck. It's still you.

question: You want to help, help me find the woman who sent this.
answer: Okay. After three years the PTR reverts to tape storage, which is okay because we access it through the CPC. Here it is. Ten packages from the same sender. Baku. Delhi. St. Petersburg. The guy was a real road warrior. This package was Kuala Lampur. No activity in his account after this package. No forwarding addresses after K.L.

question: What about the sender?
answer: Sure. Bettina Peterson. Marfa, Texas. Let's run a current check. Hmmm. Durango, Colorado; Asheville, North Carolina, then...canceled her account.

question: Can you find her?
answer: You're looking at a Level III search. For your Level III, you gotta have E-4 authorization. I don't have it.

question: Check, please. When'd you start working here?
answer: Roger got me on. I wasn't doing anything, and -- but you're back, you're really back. I would have come to Memphis, but --

question: I wanted to come here.
answer: Have some more potato salad.

question: That was great, Mom, just great. I've got all this back pay coming. Why don't you let me get you a place in town?
answer: This is my home. I'm part of the wallpaper. You miss it, don't you? You miss that island.

question: Miss that island? Mom, come on.
answer: What a journey you've had. It seems more than a person should have to bear.

question: The tide saved me, Mom. I lived by it. I'm just wondering where it will take me next.
answer: Remember the family motto. In time. It will come to you, in time.

question: FedEx for Bettina Peterson.
answer: Where did you get that?

question: Charles Noland. FedEx Special Projects.
answer: You came on a bicycle? No wonder it's so late.

question: There was an unavoidable delay.
answer: Well, I have to say, I'm impressed. You never gave up.

question: No.
answer: You know what happened to this?

question: As much as anybody.
answer: Want to come in? Get dry for a minute.

question: Okay. Sure.
answer: I've got some coffee on. Would you like some?

question: It's good.
answer: Hmmm. Feels like it might have gotten wet.

question: Possible. So you did those wings?
answer: Yeah. A long time ago.

question: They're harder to do than they look.
answer: Oh? You've tried?

question: Well, I do a little drawing -- Our apologies that it never made it to the recipient.
answer: He was a sorry sonofabitch, and I'm sorry I ever married him. You look familiar. I can't believe this. I -- I -- They are... You're a gifted artist. You're into something very powerful. Primal. Truly.

question: Well, not really, I --
answer: You are. Yes you are. What gave you the idea to paint on that cave?

question: To tell you the truth -- you did.
answer: Do you...have any more packages to deliver?

question: No. that was the last one.
answer: Just sit here, I'll get us some lunch.

question: Hey.
answer: In here!

question: That was my last one.
answer: The list of paints and brushes I did for you. Keep painting. Promise me.

question: Hey, thanks. I'd never have got that out by myself. You're not out of Pascagoula, are you?
answer: No. I used to drive one of those. A long time ago.

question: Hey, once a driver, always a driver. You want a lift? I've just got one more pickup.
answer: Sure.

question: You're Chuck Noland.
answer: Yeah. Well --

question: Yeah. Well --
answer: I knew I recognized you. My name's Erica. Did you really steal a crippled kid's bicycle to make your deliveries, or is that just some bullshit story?

question: I didn't steal it, and he wasn't crippled.
answer: Otherwise it's completely true.

question: Yeah, completely.
answer: What brings you out to the sticks?

question: Had a package to deliver.
answer: You? Personally?

question: I had it on the island with me.
answer: Must be a story there.
